data.title: John Hancock Balanced Fund Q4 2025 Commentary
data.description:
Highlights

  • In the fourth quarter, market participants experienced solid economic growth, stable credit conditions, and a modest increase in inflation.
  • The fund's equities outperformed due to favorable security selection, particularly in communication services; however, stock picking in consumer staples and real estate modestly detracted.
  • The fund's fixed-income securities outperformed, reflecting an underweight in U.S. Treasuries and an overweight in mortgage-backed securities; conversely, overweights in high-yield bonds and asset-backed securities detracted.

Market review and outlook

In Q4, market participants experienced solid economic growth, stable credit conditions, and only a modest increase in inflation. The U.S. Federal Reserve (Fed) enacted two quarter-point interest rate cuts, bringing the total reduction for the year to three-quarters of a percentage point.

Meanwhile, corporate earnings again outpaced market expectations. Although volatility was limited for the market, individual stocks saw significant divergence in performance, creating what we saw as a very favorable environment for security selection.

We expect Q4 earnings to remain strong, especially given robust holiday spending, while equity valuations appear elevated. We also anticipate increased volatility in the coming year, particularly in light of ongoing geopolitical uncertainty, the upcoming U.S. midterm elections, and divergent central bank policies.

We expect the Fed to maintain a cautious approach, and for fixed-income volatility to increase as investors navigate uncertainty regarding the future path of Fed policy. Although short-term yields declined in 2025, we believe that elevated longer-term yields could provide an attractive investment. In addition, credit fundamentals remain stable.

Contributors and detractors

The fund's equity portfolio outperformed due to strong security selection, particularly in the communication services sector. Stock picking and sector allocation—the latter of which derived from the fund's bottom-up security selection process—in healthcare also contributed. Security selection in consumer staples and real estate modestly detracted.

Individually, Eli Lilly & Company (LLY) contributed to relative performance. Shares of the pharmaceutical company rose amid continued growth in its GLP-1 drug franchise. Also contributing was Freeport-McMoRan, Inc. (FCX), a mining company that benefited from rising copper and gold prices. Alphabet, Inc. (GOOGL) further lifted the fund's relative performance.

In contrast, Zebra Technologies Corp. (ZBRA) detracted. The developer of bar-code technologies produced solid quarterly earnings that nevertheless appeared to lag investor expectations. Also hampering the fund's result was BellRing Brands, Inc. (BRBR), a maker of protein shakes. In Q4, its stock fell amid broadening concerns about heightened competition. Further detracting was the fund's lack of exposure to Apple, Inc. (AAPL), a large benchmark component that modestly outperformed the market.

For the fixed-income portfolio, which outperformed, the main contributors were an underweight in U.S. Treasuries and an overweight in mortgage-backed securities. However, overweights in high-yield bonds and asset-backed securities detracted from performance.

Portfolio changes

The fund's equity and fixed-income allocations finished 2025 at about 58% and 42%, respectively, little changed from September 30. Within the quarter, however, the fund's stock allocation rose with the market's outperformance, leading us to reduce the portfolio's equity allocation to maintain our desired underweight.

We established 7 new equity positions and sold 3 stocks from the fund. Turnover moderated but remained higher than usual, reflecting our active repositioning to take advantage of stock-level opportunities created by market volatility.

In the fixed-income portfolio, we added to the fund's securitized credit, primarily through purchases of non-agency residential MBS and non-traditional subsectors of the ABS market. In contrast, we reduced the fund's allocations to investment-grade and high-yield corporate bonds.

References

  1. It is not possible to invest in an index. Index definitions can be found within the "What you should know before Investing" section.
  2. "Net (what you pay)" represents the effect of a contractual fee waiver and/or expense reimbursement and is subject to change.
  3. Listed holdings reflect the largest portions of the fund's total and may change at any time. They are not recommendations to buy or sell any security.

data.title: SCHD: The Perfect Macro Storm Ahead
data.description:
The Schwab US Dividend Equity ETF (SCHD) is an income investor favorite and also a frequent punching bag for many backward-looking growth investors. And despite this year’s unusually strong performance, it is currently sitting exactly in the path of the perfect macroeconomic storm ahead, including President Trump’s Supreme Court disagreement (with regard to tariffs) and the Fed's great unwind (which is still only just beginning). This report reviews the fund, the macro storm ahead, and three easy alpha strategies to win with SCHD.

About SCHD

With a focus on high-quality US companies that pay healthy, growing dividends, SCHD is an income investor favorite. Its total assets have grown more than 2,700% over the last decade (to over $84 billion) as investors have piled in even though its total returns have significantly lagged the S&P 500.

(SPY) (VOO) (SP500)

Buyers often proclaim they like SCHD’s low volatility (as compared to the S&P 500) plus the perceived safety of SCHD’s blue chip holdings (which favor value-stock industries while also underweighting the growth and technology sectors that have allowed the S&P 500 to easily outperform over the last decade plus).

And it is exactly these factors that place SCHD directly in the path of the perfect macro storm ahead (as will be explained in a later section of this report).

Relative Valuation

But first, it's worth briefly considering the shifting growth/value valuation metrics since my previous SCHD article, which I also chose to share with Seeking Alpha:

  • SCHD: When the AI 'Flash Mob' Is Not For You (by Blue Harbinger)

Specifically, value stocks (such as SCHD) have been staging a strong relative comeback (both performance and valuation) as compared to growth stocks (as you can see in the following graphics).

(SPYG)

Moreover, the value stocks (to which SCHD is strongly tilted) are still relatively less expensive than growth as compared to long-term forward P/E averages.

So with that backdrop in mind, let's consider the factors placing SCHD directly in the path of the perfect macro storm ahead.

Macro Factor 1: Trump’s Supreme Court Disagreement (Tariffs and Nationalism)

Trump’s recent tariff moves (both “liberation day” in 2025 and now skating the Supreme Court’s ruling in February of 2026 via Section 122) have exacerbated certain stock market vulnerabilities.

For example, import-heavy growth and certain large-cap stocks (big tech) are now feeling the pain of an investor rotation to value and small caps (which are more tariff-resilient). And SCHD is a strong relative beneficiary (considering its tilts toward value stocks with heavy US manufacturing and more domestic revenues:

(SPYV)

  • US-Manufacturing Tilt: SCHD has higher exposure to US manufacturing than the S&P 500, primarily through its allocation to the Industrials sector (which includes most manufacturing-related companies). For example, SCHD's Industrials weighting was recently 12.1%, while the S&P 500's Industrials sector is only around 8.3%. Also, SCHD's focus on high-quality dividend payers often favors stable, established industrial and manufacturing firms (e.g., holdings like Lockheed Martin, Home Depot, and various machinery/transportation names), giving it a relative overweight in this area compared to the tech-heavy S&P 500.

  • Domestic Revenues: SCHD also has higher exposure to US (domestic) revenues in general as compared to the S&P 500. This is because SCHD consists entirely of US-listed companies (screened for consistent dividend payments and quality), which tend to derive a larger portion of their revenues from the domestic US market due to its value-oriented, defensive, and industrials-heavy tilt. In contrast, the S&P 500 has significant international revenue exposure, historically around 40%+, driven by its heavy weighting in global tech giants like Microsoft (MSFT), Apple (AAPL), and Nvidia (NVDA) that generate substantial earnings abroad.

Macro Factor 2: The Fed’s Great Unwind is only just Beginning

The decade-plus dominance of US growth stock performance has recently started to shift as value-oriented strategies (such as SCHD) are recently the leading performers (see chart below). Big reasons for this are the Fed's balance sheet unwind and—indirectly—US dollar weakness.

  • The Fed’s Balance Sheet Unwind: As you can see in the chart below, the US Fed's balance sheet is only just recently starting to shrink after a decade-plus expansion that strongly favored growth stocks and relatively punished value investors (e.g., SCHD). The balance sheet grew as part of extraordinarily stimulative monetary policies (which also included near-zero interest rates) designed to revive the economy from its near-death “Great Financial Crisis” in ‘08-’09 (and again following the covid shutdowns). Low-interest rates and free money favor growth stocks, and that has been a huge factor in the dominating performance of growth stocks.

  • US Dollar Weakness: Although less of a direct impact on SCHD’s performance, it’s also worth mentioning growing concerns about the strength of the US dollar. Specifically, the strength of the US dollar (or lack thereof) is another reason why US-domiciled global big-tech companies are underperforming recently and why non-US stocks have been a relative outperformer for US dollar-denominated investors. More specifically, growing concerns about the dollar since the US fully ditched the gold standard, have accelerated post-GFC (and even more post-COVID) as both fiscal and monetary stimulus, now combined with “trade wars,” are leading investors to question the dollar’s global-reserve-currency status (the US government lost its “AAA” credit rating) and pushing them to invest in alternatives such as gold. This slow-moving but accelerating megatrend shift (with lots of noise) is another factor that should be baked into investment decisions (more on this later).

3 Easy-Alpha Strategies: To Win with SCHD

So with those two macroeconomic megatrend factors brewing in the background (i.e. Trump’s “America First” economics and the broader US government’s disregard for the integrity of the US dollar), let’s consider their short- and long-term impacts on SCHD (in the risks section), as well as specific investment strategies to generate alpha and win big with SCHD in particular.

  1. Qualified Dividends: Depending on your tax bracket, and whether you own SCHD in a taxable or non-taxable account, is one of the most straightforward ways to add alpha (defined as the excess return of an investment relative to a benchmark). Especially when you consider SCHD’s total return potential (price appreciation plus growing dividends reinvested) as compared to other popular "higher yielding" investments that often pay non-qualified dividends (sometimes more appropriately described as "distributions"), especially considering they frequently destroy their own share prices just to maintain those glittery big distributions that yield chasers love (I share a bunch of examples here). For most investors (but certainly not all), qualified dividends are often taxed at 15%—lower than their marginal tax rate. And when you combine SCHD’s focus on qualified dividends with its focus on long-term capital appreciation (also often taxed at 15%—long-term capital gains tax rate for many investors and again lower than most investors marginal income tax rate), SCHD can be pretty darned attractive as compared to the unqualified, capital-destroying (often via return-of-capital-sourced distributions) sparkly high yields that often get way more attention than they’re worth. If peers are your benchmark—SCHD’s long-term alpha potential is attractive.

  2. Owning SCHD in an IRA—Depending on your personal situation, it can make sense to own SCHD in an Individual Retirement Account ("IRA") whereby dividends are taxed at 0% (versus often at 15% if you own it in a taxable account). Of course, there is a whole science behind whether or not to own SCHD inside or outside of an IRA (the answer depends in large part on how aggressive SCHD is relative to your other investments). But if you want to outperform your peer benchmark, owning SCHD in a tax-advantaged IRA is a quick way to add alpha (it's called "asset location" and it can add up to 0.60% of alpha, according to this popular Vanguard report).

  3. A Quasi-Bond Substitute in your Risk Budget: A lot of investors long for the days of the early 1980s when a 10-year US treasury bond offered a 15%+ annual yield and the US government still had its AAA credit rating. Alas, today we’re stuck with lower yields and higher risks on treasuries, while the stock market is way too volatile for many investors’ tastes. But rather than allocating your investments to a traditional 60/40 strategy (i.e. 60% stocks and 40% bonds) you might consider SCHD as a quasi-bond substitute (it does yield 3.3%—almost as much as that massive Vanguard Bond strategy (BND) that lands in almost every target date fund they sell), plus SCHD has more long-term price appreciation potential.

Like treasury bonds, SCHD can be a "flight to quality" investment during times of market distress, exhibiting lower beta and lower price drawdowns as compared to the S&P 500 (thanks to the high-quality blue-chip businesses it owns). And some investors comfortably outperform a 60/40 benchmark strategy by increasing their stock allocation (perhaps to say 70%) but with SCHD—a strategy they view as more attractive than investing in the full S&P 500 (which includes a massive allocation to volatile growth stocks). In this sense, SCHD can be a quasi-bond alpha-generating allocation strategy within their overall risk budget.

Risks:

Macroeconomic Sensitivity: As described earlier, SCHD has benefited from recent macroeconomic factors (such as Trump’s tariff impacts and the fed’s monetary policies), but just as quickly as these factors have benefited SCHD recently, they can create headwinds if the economic environment changes significantly.

Structural Underperformance vs. Growth-Oriented Investments: The index upon which SCHD is based has strict rules (10-year dividend history + quality screens like cash flow to debt and ROE requirements) systematically excludes or underweights high-growth companies that don't pay dividends or have shorter histories. This has caused notable lagging vs. the S&P 500 in growth-driven periods, especially since 2022 and in 2025. While SCHD can shine in value rotations (e.g. the strong start to 2026), it often misses big upside in tech/AI rallies. The opportunity cost of investing in SCHD has been very real. And if you want to pair it with a few growth stocks (for risk management reasons), consider my recent article: Ranking the Mag 7.

Heavy Sector Concentration is another risk. For example, SCHD has a big overweight to energy stocks (see graphic below) as compared to the S&P 500 (where energy is only 3.7%). And this concentration can cause the fund to underperform the market at various points in the market cycle. Also worth mentioning, SCHD has little direct exposure to real estate, as REITs for example, often don’t pay the pure qualified dividends that SCHD focuses on.

Interest Rate Sensitivity: High-dividend yield stocks often act like bond proxies whereby rising rates (or expectations thereof) can pressure valuations as investors shift to safer fixed-income alternatives. Falling rates can help, but the fund has shown varying sensitivities in past interest rate cycles.

The Bottom Line:

SCHD is up big and smoking the S&P 500 in recent months. This is a stark reversal of what happened in the 10-15 years prior as growth stocks were absolutely dominant—by a lot!

While markets are noisy, the shift towards value (such as SCHD) may be indicative of a massive long-term trend reversal and reversion to a more normal environment whereby value stocks do outperform growth (for example, that is the reality according to the 3-factor model of Nobel Prize winner Eugene Fama).

And in the real-world, macroeconomics may also support a long-term run of outperformance—for value stocks (such as SCHD) over growth stocks—that is still just barely getting started.

Especially considering the perfect storm of Trump’s Supreme Court disagreement (with regard to tariffs) as well as the massive unwind of the Fed's balance sheet (that is still only just starting) after years of dovish monetary policies that goosed growth and now increasingly call into question the strength of the US dollar.

And while many investors with different goals and different timeframes shout at each other about whether SCHD is a good investment, the reality is both sides often miss the easy alpha opportunities SCHD can provide, depending on your own personal investment situation and goals, of course.

At the end of the day, you have to do what is right for you. Disciplined, goal-focused, long-term investing continues to be a winning strategy.

data.title: QDTE: All This Work, For No Reason - Strong Sell
data.description:
Introduction

The Roundhill Innovation 100 0DTE Covered Call Strategy ETF (QDTE) is a fund that uses zero-day-to-expiry options to provide income to investors while providing overnight exposure to the Innovation 100 index (NDX) that is essentially just the Nasdaq 100. The fund generates income each morning by selling out-of-the-money 0DTE calls on the index. This is an actively managed fund. See below for additional details from their website.

Its holdings are shown below.

In the below section, we will review some macro trends and news that impact technology companies in the Nasdaq and explain why this ETF is a sell despite its underlying exposure.

Macro News and Headlines that Impact Nasdaq 100 Companies

AI Investment remains strong

There has remained significant investment in AI into the new year, especially from some of the largest and most influential companies in the space. For starters, Meta has announced major AI Chip deals with both NVIDIA Corporation (NVDA) and Advanced Micro Devices, Inc. (AMD). These were absolutely massive deals that are going to be instrumental in continuing the buildout of AI technology for a leading AI hyperscaler firm. Across all of big tech, the total spent on AI is estimated to be $650 billion just in 2026 alone, which is a monumental figure that should provide support to many of the firms in the Nasdaq. See the below graph from Bloomberg.

We believe that there will be significant amounts of spending and partnerships that will be announced throughout the rest of the year, and with interest rates seeming to head downwards, there should likely be more debt to take on more AI CapEx development. This remains bullish for technology firms in the Nasdaq.

Falling Interest Rates Should Help Fund Growth in Innovative Companies

As interest rates continue to fall through the rest of the year and into 2027, we believe that technology companies will stand to be some of the main beneficiaries of this macro news. With the new Fed Chair nominee Kevin Warsh likely set to take the helm post Jerome Powell, it is likely that rates will continue to fall. In the below graph from the St. Louis Fed, you can see that rates are still near the top of their 5-year chart, and the administration has emphasized numerous times that they would like to continue seeing rates lowered.

We believe that this ultimately will help to provide a boost for technology firms, as typically these companies thrive in low rate environments, where they can bring on debt to fund growth. This should be a bullish factor for technology companies, as long as they do not saddle on too much debt where their cash flows are unable to meet servicing requirements.

The US Government Remains Bullish on Technology

The current administration has stated numerous times that they are bullish on AI in the future, and the administration has also emphasized that they desire the US to be the center of innovation and tech in the future. The government is also currently in conversations about implementing large amounts of AI into their systems, and should continue to prove to be a tailwind for technology companies moving forward. This administration has also pushed for increased energy output to serve AI needs, and this should also help to serve as a floor for AI firms in general.

Fund Strategy

The fund employs a synthetic covered call strategy on NDX. A standard covered call strategy would involve purchasing the underlying equity (in this case, NDX) and then selling call options against that equity. In this case, the fund uses a “synthetic” strategy, meaning that instead of buying NDX outright, they purchase options in a manner that yields similar returns to owning NDX. For the purposes of this analysis, we will assume that the fund just purchases NDX directly, as the returns generally work out to be the same.

Below is a chart that compares the covered call strategy with a strategy where you just buy the underlying equity without selling covered calls. We used the following scenario for this chart:

  • Buy 100 shares of NDX at $100

  • Sell a covered call at a $110 strike for a premium of $200

We see that the covered call strategy (blue line) can be better if the price of NDX declines or only increases by a modest amount. If the price of NDX increases above a certain threshold, your gains from the covered call strategy are capped (hence why the blue line flattens out).

This means that generally, when you invest in a covered call strategy, you are predicting that the price of the underlying equity will decrease or only increase by a little. If you think the price of the equity will increase more dramatically, then the covered call strategy is not for you.

Performance

Let’s look at the performance of QDTE vs QQQ over the last year. QQQ is a Nasdaq-100 index ETF so it will yield the same performance as NDX. We do not use NDX here, as it is just an index and not a purchasable equity.

We see that both options had a very similar return. Although QDTE had better returns by 10 basis points, for most of the period QQQ had higher returns than QDTE. This is not a good sign for QDTE at all. For all of the extra effort to trade synthetic options and covered calls, the fund has only returned 0.10% more than if you just bought QQQ. Additionally, QDTE has an expense ratio of 0.97%, which is 5.39x larger than QQQ’s expense ratio of 0.18%.

In the future, we may see QDTE outperform QQQ if the positive movement of QQQ slows down or possibly goes negative. However, if you are predicting that scenario to occur, you are probably better off not owning either QDTE or QQQ.

To recap, if you bought QQQ instead of QDTE:

  • You would have 5.39x cost savings in expense ratios

  • You have no risk of gains being capped by covered calls

  • BUT historically you would have missed out on 0.10% in returns over the last year

Sounds like a good deal to us.

Risks

Tariff Conversations are Back at the Forefront

With new global tariffs of 10% (with potential promises of 15%) being implemented, there could be an impact on the overall economy and returns for NDX. If NDX does indeed decline in value (or at least not increase significantly), then a covered call strategy could prove to be a better choice.

If this risk occurs, QDTE may slightly retreat a bit but will still pay out income to investors.

AI Might Disrupt More Industries and Cause More Volatility

As we have seen with various AI announcements, such as Altruist launching a wealth management tool and Anthropic launching a cybersecurity tool, there remain lots of disruption events in the field of technology. This can cause stocks to react negatively to the news, and this might cause near-term negative swings and volatility in the underlying index.

For short-term swings on AI risks, QDTE will experience less volatility than QQQ, for instance, and will still be able to pay distributions to investors for income.

Conclusion

Technology companies as an investment are facing an era where growth should be strong and investments across public and private sectors should be tremendous. There is significant innovation and development occurring in the AI and tech sectors, and the underlying companies of the Nasdaq 100 should benefit from these tailwinds. We believe tech companies are a fantastic place for growth capital for the long run.

However, QDTE is simply the wrong path to go down. If you are bullish on NDX and big tech like we are, we recommend a non-covered call strategy (like QQQ) where your returns are not capped. We saw in the historical comparison that QDTE has provided no real marginal value to investors compared to a simple buy-and-hold strategy on NDX. We advise you to not burn any unnecessary calories nor pay any unnecessary fees and just buy a standard, cheap, big tech ETF.

data.title: U.S.-Iran Talks Advance: Iranian FM Confirms Progress On Nuclear And Sanctions Issues, Oil Prices Steady
data.description:
By Zain Vawda

The US and Iran have made a lot of progress in their latest talks, mediator Oman said on Thursday. The goal of these meetings is to settle long-term concerns over Iran's nuclear program and to prevent the US from launching new military strikes. This is happening at a tense time, as the US has been significantly increasing its military presence in the Middle East.

On Thursday, the two sides met in Switzerland for two separate sessions (one in the morning and one in the afternoon). However, they didn't speak directly; instead, officials from Oman acted as go-betweens, passing messages back and forth between:

Iran's side: Foreign Minister Abbas Araqchi.

The U.S. side: Envoys Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner.

Before the talks ended, a high-ranking Iranian official told Reuters that a basic deal is possible but only if the US stops mixing nuclear arguments with other, unrelated disagreements.

We finally heard from the Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araqchi a short while ago, who stated, "Today was one of the best, most serious & longest rounds of negotiations. We made good progress & seriously engaged with elements of a deal regarding both #nuclear & sanctions issues. We are close to an understanding on some issues, though differences remain on others."

The developments have also been having a massive impact on oil prices as well as haven demand, as it is another layer of uncertainty for market participants to consider.

What happens next?

Consultations: Officials from both countries are heading back to their capitals to discuss the progress.

Future Meetings: Formal negotiations will start again soon.

Technical Talks: Experts are scheduled to meet in Vienna next week to work on the specific details.

Omani Foreign Minister Sayyid Badr Albusaidi shared the update on X (formerly Twitter) after the most recent round of talks in Switzerland ended.

Overall risk sentiment does not appear to have been affected that much, with AI still the dominant theme, especially for equity markets.

Why did oil prices jump then fall?

When it comes to the oil market, one that has been affected by the US military buildup in the Middle East, prices were largely flat after some whipsaw price action earlier in the day.

Prices actually spiked by more than a dollar earlier in the day. This happened because reports suggested the talks had hit a wall. Specifically, the U.S. was reportedly demanding two things that Iran didn't like:

  1. That Iran stop all uranium enrichment.
  2. That Iran hand over all its highly enriched uranium to the U.S.

However, once Oman announced that "significant progress" was actually being made, prices dropped back down and lost most of those gains. Market participants are laser-focused on these talks. Here are the basic rules they are likely following right now:

If talks fail: Traders worry about war or supply problems in the Middle East, which makes oil more expensive.

If talks succeed: The risk of conflict goes down, which causes a sell-off and lowers prices.

For now, though, key support rests at the 62.66 handle (200-day MA) before the 61.67 and the 100-day MA 60.27 come into focus. A move higher from here in oil prices faces a test at the 66.15 handle before the 67.00 handle comes into play.

WTI Crude Oil Daily Chart, February 26, 2026

data.title: Why The Gold Rally Isn't Over Yet
data.description:
By Ewa Manthey, Commodities Strategist

Momentum may moderate from here. But the structural drivers underpinning the market remain firmly in place – and in some cases are strengthening.

Gold’s structural support remains intact despite January sell-off

1. Central banks are still buying

Official sector demand remains the backbone of the gold market. Since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in 2022, central banks, particularly across emerging markets, have accelerated reserve diversification in response to sanctions risk, geopolitical fragmentation and a desire to reduce reliance on the US dollar. Crucially, this demand has proved steady and largely price insensitive.

Poland, the world’s largest reported gold buyer last year, has signalled further purchases as it targets a higher absolute level of gold holdings rather than a fixed share of reserves. It is now targeting around 700 tonnes of gold, up from roughly 550 tonnes, rather than a fixed 30% share of reserves. This underscores that reserve accumulation remains strategic, not tactical.

China’s central bank also extended its gold buying to a fifteenth month in January. As long as geopolitical fragmentation persists, a meaningful reversal in central bank gold demand looks unlikely. This structural floor continues to underpin the market at elevated price levels.

Central bank demand remains resilient

2. Geopolitics back to the forefront

Geopolitical risk has re-emerged as a dominant macro driver. From renewed Middle East tensions to trade frictions and tariff threats, investors are navigating a more uncertain global environment.

Policy unpredictability, particularly around trade, is increasing volatility across asset classes. Against this backdrop, safe-haven demand remains well supported. Gold’s role as a hedge against geopolitical and policy shocks is once again in focus.

3. Fed easing could add a tailwind

A shift in the US monetary policy backdrop could provide an additional tailwind for gold. While the Federal Reserve remains cautious, the balance of risks is gradually tilting towards easing as growth momentum cools and inflation continues to normalise.

Our US economist expects the Fed to begin cutting rates in the second quarter, with policy becoming incrementally less restrictive over the coming quarters. Even a modest easing cycle would be supportive for gold, lowering real yields and reducing the opportunity cost of holding non‑yielding assets.

4. ETFs showing renewed appetite

ETF positioning remains well below the 2020 peak, leaving room for further inflows. After a period of consolidation, gold ETFs are once again attracting investor interest. While central bank buying continues to anchor the market, ETFs have the capacity to amplify price moves.

If rate‑cut expectations firm or geopolitical risks intensify, a renewed wave of ETF inflows could provide another leg higher for gold prices. Historically, ETF holdings tend to rise alongside prices and are closely linked to expectations for US monetary policy, reinforcing the case for stronger inflows as the Fed moves towards easier policy.

ETF flows respond to shifts in Fed policy

5. Digital dollars and reserve evolution

Reserve evolution is no longer confined to central banks. The rapid growth of US dollar-backed stablecoins has created a new institutional buyer of reserve assets.

Stablecoin issuers, most notably Tether, have become significant buyers of reserve assets, including US Treasuries and increasingly gold. Tether alone purchased over 70 tonnes of gold last year, second only to Poland among reported buyers, and now holds around 140 tonnes across its reserves and gold‑backed token.

If gold remains part of this reserve strategy, stablecoin growth could represent an additional structural source of demand, behaving more like central bank buying than retail flows. While still smaller in scale, this channel adds another layer of structural support.

Momentum may slow, but the case for gold remains

The path higher is unlikely to be linear. At record price levels, physical demand is becoming more price sensitive, and periods of consolidation – or short-term corrections – should be expected.

However, the structural pillars of this rally – central bank diversification, geopolitical fragmentation, potential policy easing and renewed ETF interest – remain intact. For now, the broader environment continues to favour gold.

Content Disclaimer

This publication has been prepared by ING solely for information purposes irrespective of a particular user's means, financial situation or investment objectives. The information does not constitute investment recommendation, and nor is it investment, legal or tax advice or an offer or solicitation to purchase or sell any financial instrument. Read more

data.title: DIVB: Don't Fear The AI Bubble, Diversify With Dividends And Buybacks
data.description:
Last November, I wrote an article covering the Invesco Buyback Achievers ETF (PKW) as a potential diversification strategy to avoid concentration risk of the technology-heavy S&P 500 Index (SPY). The thesis followed Michael Burry's disclosure of short positions in Nvidia (NVDA) and Palantir (PLTR), labeling AI a "bubble." PKW could hedge this risk by avoiding concentration risk in technology and focusing instead on shareholder return. This strategy proved successful, with PKW returning 6.34% and outperforming the S&P 500 by nearly 4% with less volatility. The fund focuses on buyback yield, favoring companies that are repurchasing a minimum of 5% of their float.

My only concern was PKW's relatively high total expense ratio (0.62%). Recently, I began looking at other funds that could achieve the same objective and came across the iShares Core Dividend ETF (DIVB). This fund aims to accomplish the same objective by maximizing the total capital returned to investors via dividends and buybacks. In other words, it invests in companies with the highest total shareholder return (defined as the buyback yield, plus the dividend yield). It avoids high concentration risk in individual stocks, with Exxon Mobil (XOM) being the largest holding. It also does not avoid technology, which is actually the highest-weighted sector. Instead, it favors "old" technology companies like Cisco (CSCO), Texas Instruments (TXN), and Qualcomm (QCOM) that return massive capital flows to their investors. The fund has a lower beta than the overall market (0.88) and a total expense ratio of only 0.05%.

Thus, for similar reasons as PKW, I rate DIVB a Buy for investors looking to remove technology risk from their portfolios via a simple, diversified ETF.

DIVB: The Diversification And Value Edge Vs. The S&P 500

A major difference between the S&P 500 and DIVB lies not only in which stocks they hold but in why they hold them. As a market capitalization-weighted index, the S&P 500 has become heavy in technology because these have been the best-performing stocks over the course of the current bull market. Information technology has reached around 35% because the more large technology stocks outperform, the higher the resulting weighting.

DIVB, on the other hand, gravitates toward companies that return capital to shareholders; defined as the net buyback yield plus dividend yield. Interestingly, this leads to a portfolio composition that's not extremely different from the S&P 500, except for the largest stocks in the index. Most notably, the fund is underweight information technology (24.05%), while it's overweight financials (19.72%) and energy (4.47%). On a relative basis, it's underweight communication and consumer discretionary, but this is smaller in magnitude than technology.

*Data from State Street and iShares.

While the sector weighting is not hugely different, the value bias of DIVB is considerable. DIVB has a trailing P/E ratio of 19.34x and a price/book of 2.91x. It has a very low expense ratio and a considerably higher dividend yield than either SPY or PKW. As a dividend growth investment, the fact that the portfolio is optimized toward stocks that return capital through dividends and buybacks bodes well for dividend growth, as cash flows in excess of the dividend will be directed to a smaller future float.

DIVB 19.34x 2.91 404 0.88 2.41 0.05

*Data from State Street, Invesco and iShares.

DIVB has a total return history nearly identical to PKW and lower than SPY, but it's outperforming so far year-to-date as AI fears have weighed on the market. Given the fund's lower beta, the risk-adjusted return is nearly equal to SPY and better than PKW. Over the past 10 years, investors essentially had to endure more volatility to receive the same return as PKW.

In summary, the total return mandate of DIVB ensures that the fund focuses on mature, free cash flow-rich companies. It's not expected to outperform if the present bull market continues unabated, but it may reduce risk via diversification should the valuations of the highest-performing stocks decline. Given its underweight position in information technology, the fund has more of a value weighting than the S&P 500.

Total Return Achievers: Stocks That Define The Strategy

In a market that has been dominated by AI fears, DIVB weights toward steady, large-cap stocks that return substantial portions of their massive cash flows back to investors.

Interestingly, the top 10 companies in the fund contributed 27.2% of the total, with none larger than a 4.7% weighting. Of these stocks, the average dividend yield (2.80%) was roughly matched by the buyback yield (2.81%).

Average -- -- $327.2B 2.72% 2.80% 2.81%

*Data From Morningstar.

The amount of "hidden" yield from stock repurchases roughly equals the dividends paid among the top ten stocks in the fund. While these companies are not the fast-growing stocks that excite growth investors, they're stable, large, and prudently managed companies that are likely to hold up better than the overall market should AI fears come to pass.

Is Michael Burry Correct About the Market 'Bubble?'

The S&P 500 is more concentrated than at almost any time in history. This is undeniable, as the graphic below illustrates. The percentage of market capitalization residing in the top 10 stocks is higher than at any time in history, except 1929.

In 1929, investors speculated enormously, using leverage to buy the top growth stocks of the time. Ultimately, this created an unstable bubble propped up by margin loans. When the top stocks fell, investors were forced to sell, creating a self-reinforcing cycle of falling prices and liquidation. While the economy was slowing before the market crashed, the loss of investor confidence cemented the Great Depression. Today, similar levels of concentration exist, which is concerning given how quickly the price of the largest technology stocks can move.

Perhaps unsurprisingly, none of the hottest growth stocks of the 1920s remain near the top of today's S&P 500. While many still exist, they're a fraction of their former weight in the index. General Motors (GM), General Electric (GE), and DuPont (DD) trade to this day, while others have merged or been acquired over the years.

If our current market is in a "bubble," then it's very different from the valuation bubble that ended in 2000, with the possible exception of Tesla (TSLA). With Tesla, the average of the top nine big tech companies trades at 48.1x forward earnings. However, without Tesla, this drops to 26.0x. The equal weighted S&P 500 (RSP), in contrast, trades for ~17.8x forward earnings.

While this is a premium, the expected annual growth of these big tech firms in the next 3-5 years is 23.6%, presenting a favorable average PEG ratio of 1.90x. In particular, Nvidia (NVDA) and Microsoft (MSFT) appear quite cheap relative to their growth. Furthermore, these firms present quality earnings that have commanded a premium multiple to the market in past years.

Average

*Data from State Street and Seeking Alpha.

However, Michael Burry's case is more nuanced than a simple P/E ratio. He believes that the huge spending on chips and data centers has led to understated depreciation. If he is correct, it will lead to pressure on the earnings of big tech in the coming years, pressuring the long-term earnings growth expected by analysts. As I have previously written, the sheer magnitude of big tech capex spending is breathtaking. It's roughly $700B this year and potentially $1T next year.

I think there's some confusion among investors about the growth that big tech is currently pursuing. Not all growth creates value. There's no question that big tech will see phenomenal revenue growth in the coming years due to AI demand. The question is whether big tech is spending so much today that the discounted value of those cash flows will be insufficient to create value for shareholders.

To quote my favorite investor, Warren Buffett:

Growth benefits investors only when the business in point can invest at incremental returns that are enticing—in other words, only when each dollar used to finance the growth creates over a dollar of long-term market value. In the case of a low-return business requiring incremental funds, growth hurts the investor.

Therefore, there is substantial risk to investors in big tech. The risk is not that demand for AI will evaporate, and it's not that the companies are overvalued based on a reasonable forecast of cash flow. Rather, the risk is that the huge spending today will eventually generate multiple AI products that will become commoditized. Further, the capex required to fund this growth is extremely high, leading to a pincer attacking the value of cash flow from multiple angles.

If Google (GOOG), Meta (META), Microsoft (via OpenAI and Copilot), and Amazon (AMZN) (via Anthropic) all profit from AI, there are only two possibilities. One is they all reach roughly the same product, and that product is a commodity. The second is that only a few win, but the rest must lose. Thus, the eventual return on investment for AI is uncertain. It's even possible that the return will become so low that we look back years from now, acknowledging that Burry was correct in his "bubble" call.

Conclusion

The S&P 500 has become concentrated in a few growth companies to a degree only witnessed in 1929. While the growth promised by AI and modern technology is undeniable, the spending to achieve that growth calls returns into question. Investors should remember Warren Buffett's advice: Growth only creates value when the return on invested capital is high; otherwise, it can ultimately destroy shareholder value. To be clear: I do not present this as a bear thesis for the S&P 500, it's simply a risk that growth-oriented investors are taking. My primary concern about the S&P 500 is that rather than being diversified, the largest companies in it are taking similar risks. This could end well or badly depending on the eventual returns from investment in AI.

By traditional DCF metrics, the largest companies in the S&P 500 appear reasonably valued. However, these businesses are in transition, and investing in them today is a bet that AI will offer sufficient return on capital to create shareholder value. For investors who wish to diversify, the iShares Core Dividend ETF (DIVB) offers a highly efficient way to maintain exposure preferentially to companies that are returning capital to shareholders instead of spending it on AI. By focusing on the dual engine of shareholder yield (dividends plus share buybacks), DIVB rewards investors with massive capital flows while presenting lower volatility than the broader market.

In addition, we have witnessed in the past several weeks how quickly individual stocks can suffer massive drawdowns. In this respect, DIVB spreads capital over around four hundred stocks, avoiding potentially catastrophic single-stock concentration risk. As I feared when speculating about "The Great Commoditization," the companies that suffer may be those investing in AI and those whose business models are suddenly called into question.

For these reasons, DIVB is a compelling Buy offering: Low volatility, high diversification, and certain return on capital through dividends and buybacks.

data.title: Gas Prices Up For Sixth Straight Week, Longest Streak Since 2023
data.description:
By Jennifer Nash

Gas prices rose for a sixth straight week, the longest streak since 2023. As of February 23rd, the price of regular gas was up 1 cent and the price of premium gas was up 2 cents from the previous week. According to GasBuddy.com, California has the highest average price for regular at $4.59, and Oklahoma has the cheapest at $2.33.

Currently, the national average price for a gallon of regular gasoline stands at $2.94, with premium gasoline averaging $3.92 per gallon. One year ago, regular gas was priced at $3.13 per gallon, while premium gas was at $4.08 per gallon.

Gas Prices: Inflation-Adjusted Reality

The volatility in crude oil and gasoline prices has been clearly reflected in recent years in both the consumer price index (CPI) and personal consumption expenditures (PCE). In this next chart, we take a look at the same gasoline prices shown in the first chart but adjust for inflation using the CPI.

For an easier way to visualize the effects of inflation, this next chart overlays the nominal price with the real price for each type of gasoline (regular and premium).

Components of Gasoline Retail Price

The retail price of gas is made up of four main components: 1) cost of crude oil, 2) refining costs and profits 3) distribution and marketing costs and profits, and 4) taxes.

West Texas Intermediate Oil

This next chart shows the West Texas light crude oil price over the past 8 months. As of February 23rd, WTIC end-of-day spot price for crude oil closed at $66.31, up 6.4% from the previous week and the highest level since July.

The next chart is a monthly chart overlay of West Texas light crude, Brent crude, and unleaded gasoline end-of-day spot prices.

ETFs associated with gasoline, WTIC crude oil, and Brent crude oil include United States Gasoline Fund LP (UGA), United States Oil Fund LP (USO), United States Brent Oil Fund LP (BNO), and Invesco DB Oil Fund (DBO).

data.title: Insulet: The Growth Doesn't Stop Here
data.description:
Thesis Overview

I rate Insulet Corporation (PODD) a buy at the current price level, with my model reflecting +35% upside and a 12-month price target of $330. These are based on 3 primary pillars: (1) The market is overstating the impact of GLP-1s, (2) International expansion represents untapped growth opportunity, and (3) The Type 2 Diabetes (T2D) market has low penetration rates, and PODD is set to benefit the most with its structural moat and FCL development.

The Company

Insulet is a medical device company that's in the business of developing, manufacturing, and selling their Omnipod System — a tubeless, wearable insulin management and delivery system. Traditional insulin delivery systems include subcutaneous methods (injections, pens) that require multiple daily self-administered injections (MDI), which enable both basal and bolus insulin release. Insulin pumps are small devices that contain a continuous supply of insulin through a tiny tube inserted under the skin to deliver both basal and bolus insulin. Finally, we have automated insulin delivery systems. This is the niche in which Insulet operates with its Omnipod products. These are devices that create one comprehensive system, including a continuous glucose monitor (CGM), an insulin pump, and algorithms that automatically manage and adjust insulin delivery in real time. Together, these minimize human error through manual calculations and increase convenience as they don’t need to be self-administered; the whole process is automated.

The Omnipod system is a tubeless, waterproof, wearable pod with a complementary app to administer bolus insulin. Similar automated insulin delivery (AID) devices still require patients to calculate carbohydrates in meals to administer bolus insulin before meals. Omnipod facilitates this through their SmartBolus calculator feature in the app, which recommends a dose level, after which patients click confirm, and the system delivers the amount. The pod contains their algorithm, which is paired with CGM systems to automatically adjust and regulate insulin delivery every 5 minutes. What’s unique about this device is its recurring revenue through its almost subscription-like elements. Each pod has a lifespan of 72 hours, creating the need to constantly replace them. The FDA cleared these pods in January 2022 for use in type 1 diabetics aged 2 years and above and type 2 diabetics aged 18 years and above.

PODD has 3 primary streams of revenue: US (71%), International (28%), and Drug Delivery (1%). Their US segment accounts for revenues from the sale of Omnipod products (the current Omnipod 5 and legacy Omnipod DASH). The international segment accounts for the sale of Omnipod products across the US border. Finally, their Drug Delivery segment refers to revenues from PODD partnering with other firms to use their tubeless pods to deliver non-insulin drugs. As per their 10K, they primarily sell pods to Amgen here.

Earnings and Financials

Earnings blew it out of the park! We saw revenues climb 31% year over year to 783 million. We saw an EPS surprise of over 4%. We saw international Omnipod revenue grow over 50% year over year, showing us how their international expansion represents a real long-term growth opportunity, as I’ll discuss later in this report. The main takeaways from the earnings were that it reflects the underpenetrated international market and the massive opportunity it represents, the exploding adoption of Omnipod 5 and its mass appeal as a leading tubeless AID insulin pump, and the authorization of a 300 million share repurchase program. The company generated a 24% increase in FCF on a year-on-year basis, and there’s a massive runway for further value creation to shareholders as demonstrated by this buyback program. Moreover, their current ratio, at 2.81, reflects high liquidity and more than solid coverage of short-term obligations. Their total debt level of $949 million, implying a d/e ratio of 0.63x, is well covered by $716 million in cash. Insulet boasts strong margin expansion driven by the success of Omnipod 5 and its launch in international markets. We’ve seen a +184 bps increase in gross margins from 2024 to 71.6%, well above their peers of Medtronic plc (MDT) (65%) and Tandem Diabetes Care, Inc. (TNDM) (54%). Furthermore, their operating margin has grown by +54 bps to 15.5%. The decline in net profit margin is driven by a one-time non-operating expense (loss on extinguishment of debt) and a normalized tax expense as opposed to the tax benefit received previously. The underlying business demonstrates great growth.

Industry and Competitive Dynamics

Currently, the adult population (people aged 20-79 years) of diabetics has reached almost 600 million and is expected to grow by 45% to over 850 million by 2050.

Of this, Type 2 diabetes (T2D) accounts for over 90% of all diabetes cases worldwide. Type 1 diabetes (T1D) is a chronic autoimmune condition that destroys insulin-producing cells in the pancreas. Once destroyed, these cells are not replaced; therefore, these patients require an external source of insulin as their bodies no longer have enough insulin-producing beta cells. T1D patients are treated with insulin, which is administered through injections, pens, pumps, and AID systems like Omnipod 5. On the other hand, T2D patients still have insulin-producing cells; however, they develop a resistance to it. These patients are treated with a broad range of drugs and, depending on the severity of the diabetes, are given MDIs and placed on pumps.

The insulin delivery device market was valued at 20B in 2024 and is projected to reach $43 billion by 2033 at a CAGR of 8.8%. Within this broader pump market, the niche of AID devices and the insulin patch industry, the very one that Omnipod 5 lies in, is projected to see even greater growth.

As it stands, Insulet’s only direct competitors are Medtronic’s MiniMed 780G and Tandem’s Mobi. Medtronic is the largest company and has captured the majority of the market with its MiniMed 780G (released in 2023), having captured 36% of the insulin pump market. However, PODD has positioned itself as the best all-encompassing product in the market with Omnipod 5’s tubeless nature, CGM, automated insulin adjustment algorithm, and app-based control and deployment.

Insulet’s market share of the insulin pump market exceeds 25%, and it continues to aggressively steal market share from the competition. The market is concerned with the future competitive landscape of the pump market, as in the near term (early 2026), Tandem is coming out with Tubeless Mobi, a tubeless AID device with a product lifespan of 7 days compared to Omnipod 5’s 3-day lifespan. After this, Tandem hopes to launch Sigi, a 7-day, tubeless AID device that seeks to differentiate itself and capture market share for its rechargeable capability. Moreover, Medtronic is set to submit its own tubeless model for FDA approval in late 2026. The threat here lies in Medtronic’s deep pockets, considering it is a much larger company with an almost $130 billion market cap, a massive installed base, and prior relationships, which would allow it to recapture market share if successful.

Insulet responds by developing Omnipod 6, currently enrolled in trial phases, and expected to submit by the end of 2026 and launch in 2027. They release the results of their trials at the American Diabetes Association (ADA) 2026 conference. Given Omnipod 5's strong clinical performance, boasting 80% Time in Range (TIR), I expect Omnipod 6 to reflect similarly strong trials given its adaptive AI learning algorithm. Furthermore, their fully closed-loop device is in the early clinical stage, set to launch in 2028. There are 3 primary pump types: open loop, fully user-controlled; hybrid closed loop, automated with the occasional need for user input; and closed loop, fully automated. Insulet and the majority of its competitors are hybrid-closed loop, in that they fully automate basal insulin doses based on glucose trends reflected in the CGM; however, they require users to manually program bolus insulin dose amounts based on the carb count of their meals. Insulet’s SmartBolus Calculator recommends a bolus dose amount based on user-input data to facilitate the process, and once accepted, it administers the dose.

The Market is Overstating the Impact of GLP-1s

Glucagon Like Peptides (GLP-1) drugs are a class of medication that help manage blood sugar (glucose) levels in people with type 2 diabetes. GLP-1 is a naturally occurring hormone that your small intestine produces: triggering insulin from the pancreas, blocking glucagon secretion, and satiating oneself. These drugs aren’t yet FDA-approved to treat type 1 diabetes. Type 1 diabetes is a chronic autoimmune condition that destroys insulin-producing cells in the pancreas. Once destroyed, these cells are not replaced. Conversely, type 2 diabetes still has insulin-producing cells that do so, but in fact, they become resistant to it. Therefore, GLP-1 drugs have no impact on treating type 1 diabetes, as they enhance insulin secretion, but type 1 diabetics suffer from the body destroying their own insulin-producing beta cells.

The market believes that the emergence of GLP-1 and SGLT2 inhibitors poses a direct threat to insulin delivery devices, with shares in the past dropping almost 12% because of GLP-1 news, but is overstating this impact. There is a fundamental misalignment between what it believes the relationship between GLP-1s and insulin delivery devices is and what the reality of the situation is. GLP-1s cannot effectively treat type 1 diabetes, and PODD serves a customer base of predominantly type 1 diabetics. Moreover, within their type 2 diabetes customer base, they target exclusively individuals placed on intensive insulin therapy. These patients require multiple daily injections (MDI) and are beyond the point where GLP-1s alone would be effective.

The emergence of GLP-1s doesn't place any direct threat to Insulet’s current customer base (T1D patients and T2D patients placed on intensive insulin therapy). One may think, “Ok, it doesn’t affect their current market, but won’t GLP-1s reduce the number of patients that reach the point where they need intensive insulin therapy, and therefore reduce the future market size?” I argue the contrary; industry experts such as Dr. Osama Hamdy have elucidated that GLP-1s complement the insulin delivery devices industry, increasing the need for constant glucose monitors (CGMs). With Omnipod being one of the best quality, all-encompassing tools on the market, integrated with CGM, bolus insulin administering app with their SmartBolus Calculator feature, and convenience (through a waterproof feature, being tubeless, and being small), it creates sticky demand as new customers will favor Omnipod 5 over others in the market.

Insulet’s International Expansion Focus Represents Untapped Growth

PODD’s international segments currently account for almost 30% of revenue. Historically, this segment has had little to no revenue growth until 2023. In 2024, we saw international revenue growth outpace US Omnipod revenue by over 7% (28% vs 21%), and it has upheld that trend in the following quarters. This reflects the existence of a time lag between when Omnipod 5 first launched in international markets and when the growth materialized into a contribution to top-line growth. Omnipod 5 has only just launched in European markets, arriving in Germany and the UK in 2023, and since then has expanded into 9 countries. What I find interesting is that this is an active expansion; it’s ongoing, with them bringing Omnipod 5 to various other countries in 2026 and expanding focus into the Middle East. Having just entered many European nations as recently as March 2025, I expect to see great growth trends. My thesis lies in the opportunity that the Europe and Middle East expansion represents. As mentioned earlier, the majority of PODD’s revenue comes from type 1 diabetics, and Europe has the highest population of type 1 diabetics, and it's growing.

Moreover, the MENA region, as portrayed by the graph earlier, represents the second-largest addressable market, with the diabetes population forecasted to grow 92% by 2050. This will drive further TAM expansion from their current $30 billion level.

T2D Market is Underpenetrated

Global diabetes is expected to grow 46% by 2050. 90% of the diabetic population are Type 2 diabetics. However, the T2D market is quite underpenetrated, with extremely low 5% adoption rates for insulin pumps. This 5% rate is projected to reach 15% by 2027. Insulet is set to see the largest gains from this based on two key factors: their structural moat as the best tubeless AID device on the market and their distribution channel strategy. Their moat lies in the fact that they're the most prominent tubeless devices on the market, and their tubeless nature makes them less visible and more discreet. Moreover, most of their major competitors rely on traditional paths where insulin pumps are distributed through Durable Medical Equipment (DME) channels. This is often a complex and heavily regulated path, which brings along a lot of paperwork, security, and insurance guidelines. Additionally, this model typically locks consumers into a large, long-term contract wherein they pay a high upfront cost to use the product. However, Insulet benefits from being the first in the market to establish the pay-as-you-go model in which consumers pay for pods as needed, rather than being fixed into long-term contracts. This makes Omnipod 5 a more affordable and more convenient option, setting Insulet to lead the T2D penetration. Insulet’s historically high FCF margins also demonstrate a wide runway for reinvestment into R&D and developing their fully closed-loop devices aimed specifically at providing complete AID devices for people with T2D.

Risks

The largest risk the market remains cautious of is the competitive landscape. As mentioned earlier, Tandem is coming out with Tubeless Mobi, with a superior product lifespan of 7 days compared to Omnipod 5’s 3-day lifespan, as well as Sigi, unique for its rechargeable capability. Medtronic is set to submit its own tubeless model for FDA approval in late 2026, which, if approved, poses a major threat with its deeper pockets, massive installed base, and prior relationships, allowing MDT to recapture market share if successful. Furthermore, their success does require continued conversion of patients on MDI and competing pump systems. Delays in FDA approval, technical challenges, or slower-than-expected clinician adoption could also hinder revenue growth (regulatory clearance of enhancements to Omnipod 5 and the planned launch of Omnipod 6).

Valuation

Based solely on comparable company analysis, the stock seems to be trading at a higher relative valuation, which, at face value, may seem indicative of overvaluation. However, I argue that this represents the premium investors are willing to pay for the stock for the expected future growth.

I’ve created a comprehensive financial model with revenue build, operating model, and supporting schedules, all of which plug into a DCF, which indicates an implied share price of $330, suggesting a +35% upside.

The assumptions that were built into the model were a gradual shift towards international revenue increasing in value in the revenue mix based on strong growth as they expand into MENA markets. Additionally, this thought process was based on the fact that there is strong competition in the US markets in the near future, with various firms, as discussed earlier, expanding their AID market footprint, which I believe would eventually lead to a slight decline in ASP in order to stay competitive and compete with the behemoth that is MDT. I did, however, forecast this to normalize eventually into a 70/30 US/International revenue mix. Moreover, my assumptions were driven by the idea that PODD’s future sales are a reflection of a stable, growing installed base rather than episodic sales. I forecast end-of-period (EOP) installed base to grow at an aggressive CAGR of almost 20%, driven by the broader market appeal Omnipod 5 generates as an all-encompassing tubeless AID device, T2D penetration, and international expansion. The output is based on an 8.92% WACC and a 2.5% PGR.

Conclusion

Based on all that is discussed in this report, I believe Insulet is a buy with a 12-month price target of $330, representing 35% upside. GLP-1 concerns are exaggerated, with Insulet’s core customer base of T1D and T2D patients on intensive insulin therapy unaffected. International expansion and shifting focus into the Middle East represent strong growth prospects (with +50% YoY growth). The T2D market is still underpenetrated, giving PODD a large runway for growth, with pump adoption expected to triple to 15% by 2027. The 2026 ADA conference will be something to look out for as a near-term catalyst, as well as the continued success of international growth driven by active European market expansion. At an 8.92% WACC and 2.5% PGR, my DCF reflects a $330 implied share price backed by reasonable assumptions. The growth has only just begun.

data.title: Virtus Terranova U.S. Quality Momentum ETF Q4 2025 Commentary
data.description:
Index Composition

The Terranova U.S. Quality Momentum Index filters securities based on positive technical momentum and then ranks them by measures of fundamental quality. This results in an equally weighted portfolio of 125 well-established U.S. securities. The Index is rebalanced and reconstituted quarterly, based on technical factors.

Market Review

The fourth quarter of 2025 continued the prevailing bullish trend that had been in place for U.S. equities since October 2022. However, and more importantly for investors, the fourth quarter provided continued evidence of a healthier investing environment relative to the narrower market opportunities of the prior two years.

Often underappreciated is the calmness on display in the U.S. corporate and government debt markets. During the fourth quarter, the U.S. 10-year Treasury traded neatly in a range between 3.93% and 4.20%, despite a U.S. government shutdown. Supported by two 25 basis point rate cuts from the Federal Reserve (the Fed), the cost of capital continued trending lower with a modest improvement in the availability of credit. Emerging markets debt, municipal bonds, high yield, and investment grade debt all posted gains in the fourth quarter.

For the emerging markets and developed international equity markets, the fourth quarter of 2025 was the exclamation point on a year of relative outperformance to the U.S. The Nikkei 225 Index advanced 12% in the fourth quarter, contributing to developed international equities outperforming the U.S. Strong equity performance in Korea, Taiwan, and China contributed to similar outperformance, relative to the U.S., for emerging markets equities.

Corporate earnings continued to anchor the secular bull market for U.S. equities. During the fourth quarter, the S&P 500® Index ('SPX') posted 13.2% earnings growth and 8.3% revenue growth. Ten of the 11 major SPX sectors witnessed positive earnings growth, with only energy down a modest 1.7%. Technology, financials, and materials all recorded double-digit earnings growth. SPX profit margins rose to another new all-time high at 14%, blunting the effect of global tariffs with SPX companies' ability to absorb tariff costs.

Value outperformed growth for SPX companies in the fourth quarter, led by a resurgence for health care, the best performing SPX sector during the quarter. Precious and base metals had parabolic advances to new all-time highs, which supported the earnings of the materials sector. Lower crude oil prices supported consumers and goods producers, with spot crude oil ending 2025 at $57.42, its lowest annual average price since 2020.

How the Fund Performed

Performance was in line with the Terranova U.S. Quality Momentum Index throughout the quarter, with nominal tracking error. For the quarter, JOET posted a total return of -1.56% at NAV versus the Index's return of -1.49%. For comparative purposes, the S&P 500® Index returned 2.66%, while the S&P 500® Equal Weight Index returned 1.39%. For the one-year period, JOET posted a total return of 12.10% at NAV versus the Index's return of 12.49%. For comparative purposes, the S&P 500® Index returned 17.88% over the same period, while the S&P 500® Equal Weight Index returned 11.43%.

The Fund is an exchange-traded fund ("ETF"). The "net asset value" ('NAV') of the Fund is determined at the close of each business day, and represents the dollar value of one share of the Fund; it is calculated by taking the total assets of the Fund, subtracting total liabilities, and dividing by the total number of shares outstanding. The NAV of the Fund is not necessarily the same as its intraday trading value. Fund investors should not expect to buy or sell shares at NAV because shares of ETFs such as the Fund are bought and sold at market price (not NAV) and are not individually redeemed from the Fund. Thus, shares may trade at a premium or discount to their NAV in the secondary market. Brokerage commissions will reduce returns. NAV returns are calculated using the Fund's daily 4:00 p.m. NAV, and include the reinvestment of all dividends and other distributions (reinvested at the Fund's NAV on distribution ex-date). Market price returns are calculated using the 4:00 pm closing price, and include the reinvestment of all dividends and other distributions (reinvested at the closing price on distribution ex-date). Prior to January 1, 2026, the market price returns were calculated using the 4:00 pm midpoint between the bid and offer prices. Market price returns do not represent the return you would receive if you traded at other times.

Index 1: The Terranova U.S. Quality Momentum Index is an equally weighted index designed to provide diversified exposure to quality momentum large-cap equities listed in the United States. The index is calculated on a total return basis with dividends reinvested. Index 2: The S&P 500® Index is a free-float market capitalization-weighted index of 500 of the largest U.S. companies. The indexes are calculated on a total return basis with dividends reinvested. Index 3: The S&P 500® Equal Weight Index is an equal-weighted index of 500 of the largest U.S. companies. The index is calculated on a total return basis with dividends reinvested.

The MSCI USA Momentum Index is designed to capture the performance of an equity momentum strategy by emphasizing stocks with high price momentum. The MSCI USA Quality Index is designed to capture the performance of quality growth stocks by identifying stocks with high quality scores based on high return on equity ('ROE'), stable year-over-year earnings growth, and low financial leverage. The Nasdaq Composite® Index is a market capitalization-weighted index that tracks all securities listed on the Nasdaq stock exchange. The S&P MidCap 400® Index is a free-float market-capitalization weighted index of 400 mid-cap U.S. companies that measures the performance of the mid-cap segment of the market. The index is calculated on a total return basis with dividends reinvested. The Russell 2000® Index is a free float-adjusted market capitalization-weighted index of the 2,000 smallest companies in the Russell Universe, which comprises the 3,000 largest U.S. companies. The index is calculated on a total return basis with dividends reinvested. The indices are unmanaged, their returns do not reflect any fees, expenses, or sales charges, and are not available for direct investment.

Tracking Error is the divergence between the price behavior of a position or a portfolio and the price behavior of a benchmark.

IOPV, or Indicative Optimized Portfolio Value, is a calculation disseminated by the stock exchange that approximates the Fund's NAV every fifteen seconds throughout the trading day.

Notes on Risk: Exchange-Traded Funds ('ETF'): The value of an ETF may be more volatile than the underlying portfolio of securities it is designed to track. The costs to the portfolio of owning shares of an ETF may exceed the cost of investing directly in the underlying securities. Large-sized companies may enhance that risk. Equity Securities: The market price of equity securities may be adversely affected by financial market, industry, or issuer-specific events. Focus on a particular style or on small, medium, or large-sized companies may enhance that risk. Momentum Factor Investing: Momentum investing is subject to the risk that the securities may be more volatile than the market as a whole. There may be periods when the momentum style of investing is out of favor and therefore, the investment performance of the portfolio may suffer. Passive Strategy/Index Risk: A passive investment strategy seeking to track the performance of the underlying index may result in the portfolio holding securities regardless of market conditions or their current or projected performance. This could cause the portfolio's returns to be lower than if the portfolio employed an active strategy. Market Price/NAV: At the time of purchase and/or sale, an investor's shares may have a market price that is above or below the fund's NAV, which may increase the investor's risk of loss. Correlation to Index: The performance of the portfolio and its index may vary due to factors such as flows, transaction costs, whether the portfolio obtains every security in the index, and timing differences associated with additions to and deletions from the index. Market Volatility: The value of the securities in the portfolio may go up or down in response to the prospects of individual companies and/or general economic conditions. Local, regional, or global events such as war or military conflict, terrorism, pandemic, or recession could impact the portfolio, including hampering the ability of the portfolio's manager(s) to invest its assets as intended.
