data.title: NVIDIA: Jensen Just Raised The AI Bar (Again), Buy The Post-Earnings Dip
data.description:
NVIDIA (NVDA) popped, then dropped in the hours after reporting Q4 earnings on Wednesday, February 25. By the following morning, shares were down modestly, which seemed to counter what was a gangbuster set of revenue and profit figures. Free cash flow was also strong, as AI hyperscaler capex is NVIDIA’s gain.

Indeed, we are in a different environment compared to two or three years ago. The bar is simply higher for the world’s most valuable company. I had a "Buy" rating on NVDA back in January, following a generally successful CES. The stock, for now, remains below the top of a key trading range (which I will detail later), and NVIDIA’s GTC AI event is now in focus.

NVDA is up 8% since my previous analysis. Today, I reiterate a "Buy" rating and am raising my price target based on the robust Q4 numbers.

NVIDIA Leader to Laggard Lately

NVIDIA EPS Rising, Share Price Stalled

NVIDIA Has Moved Little After Recent Earnings Reports

In February, NVIDIA reported a strong set of quarterly results. Q4 non-GAAP EPS of $1.62 topped the Wall Street consensus forecast of $1.54, while revenue of $68.1 billion, up a whopping 73% from the same period last year, was a healthy $1.9 billion beat.

Jensen Huang’s company achieved record Data Center net sales, +22% sequentially and +75% YoY, with record firm-wide revenue of $215.9 billion for the full year. Guidance also blew past analysts’ expectations.

NVIDIA: Segment Results

Shares were down 3% by the following morning, marking yet another somewhat muted post-earnings performance. The options market had priced in a 7.5% earnings-related stock price swing based on the at-the-money straddle expiring this week. I expect implied volatility to cool from near 50% before the numbers hit to perhaps 30%-35% in the days ahead... but volatility may present itself in mid-March around the AI GTC event.

Looking back on the quarter that was, it was a record-breaking Q4 and year for the $4.8 trillion market cap company. The stellar growth was primarily driven by, of course, its Data Center segment, where revenue surged due to $51.3 billion in net sales from compute and $11.0 billion from networking. Jensen noted intense demand for the firm’s Blackwell, Hopper, and Ampere-based architectures.

NVIDIA: Revenue Highlights

NVIDIA's GAAP gross margin improved to 75.0%, and GAAP diluted EPS nearly doubled YoY to $1.76. Additionally, NVIDIA generated $34.9 billion in free cash flow and returned $8.1 billion to shareholders through stock repurchases and a small dividend.

Looking ahead to the first quarter of fiscal year 2027, the company anticipates further revenue growth to approximately $78.0 billion.

NVIDIA: Major FCF Growth

On the call, Jensen introduced a paradigm shift in how investors should view AI spending. He argued that for NVIDIA's customers, compute is no longer a cost center, but a revenue generator. Because of "token monetization," every dollar spent on a Blackwell or Rubin rack directly translates to the ability to sell AI tokens (inference). He noted that "the cash issues will be resolved by the cash flows of AI factories being much better than expected."

Now, Jensen is first and foremost an innovator, but he’s also a salesman. He centered on agentic AI when speaking with analysts. But along with the intriguing and inspiring narrative, the CEO confirmed that while the market is just beginning to digest Blackwell, NVIDIA has already shipped its first Vera Rubin samples to customers.

What’s more, the firm has diversified into so-called "Sovereign AI,” exposing itself to countries and not just the major domestic AI hyperscalers. This is a bullish factor that should sustain at least a market P/E multiple.

On the earnings outlook, EPS growth is expected to rise from $8.25 in the current fiscal year to above $10 in the out year. By FY 2029, NVIDIA could approach $13 in operating per-share earnings. With annual revenue gains and impressive operating leverage, the earnings picture remains sanguine.

Not surprisingly, we saw 21 sell side EPS upgrades in the previous 90 days, compared to just a trio of downgrades. Finally, profitability trends are likewise impressive, with free cash flow per share before the Q4 numbers of $3.17.

NVIDIA: Revenue & Earnings Forecasts, EPS Revision Trends

On valuation, I have updates to my previous numbers. If we assume $8.40 of forward 12-month non-GAAP EPS and apply a 28x multiple, then shares should trade near $235.

I increased the earnings assumption due to the period shift and Q4 beat, but lowered the multiple as the firm diversifies and amid slightly higher risks in the AI trade.

NVDA: Very Low PEG Ratio, Modest P/E

Key risks include a capex slowdown among the AI hyperscalers, given the big investment growth announced in recent weeks. The new tax policy incentivizes capex, and that may pull forward out-year AI projects.

More broadly, a global macroeconomic slowdown would likely reduce enterprise spending on AI, while increased competition from other global semiconductor companies will likely result in lower margins in the year ahead. The trade war appears to be a smaller risk today, but geopolitical risks remain elevated, which could impact the supply chain.

For sure, ASIC customer AI chip development from AI names is a possible risk, but NVIDIA continues to bring training and inference costs down, which helps defend NVIDIA's GPUs.

In the near term, reduced profitability among software companies could call into question the broader AI growth narrative.

Risk: NVIDIA Is Dependent on AI Hyperscaler Capex

Competitor Analysis

Looking ahead, corporate event data provided by Wall Street Horizon show a confirmed Q1 2027 earnings date of Wednesday, May 20 AMC. The company’s flagship GTC AI Conference takes place starting on Monday, March 16, so we could see added volatility that week.

Corporate Event Calendar

The Technical Take

With shares responding modestly positively to the Q4 report, NVDA’s technical situation may be turning more bullish. Notice in the chart below that the stock—trading at $190 as of this writing—may be poised to finally close above a key range dating back to November 10. The stock still has work to do, and the Friday (weekly) settle will be even more important. But should we get the breakout, then a measured move upside price objective of about $222 would be in play—just below my intrinsic value target.

But take a look at the RSI momentum oscillator at the top of the graph. It, like price, has been range bound. A share-price rally paired with an RSI breakout is what we want to see. The long-term 200-day moving average, meanwhile, remains on the rise, suggesting that the bulls control the primary trend. The stock did hit $207 right after the earnings report, while the all-time high of $212 is near-term resistance.

Assuming a breakout, $196 would become support (former resistance becomes new support). Longer-term support is down at $153.

NVDA: Bullish Upside Breakout Possible, Monitoring the RSI

The Bottom Line

I have a "Buy" rating on NVDA. Today, after the Q4 report, I am raising my price target and feel more confident that a technical breakout may soon occur.
